fact: Keep going, you're on the right track!
Approximately 13 kilometers of wire connects the electrical power system aboard the ISS.
At 400km, we've reached the average orbit height of the ISS. Of course, unless it's directly above you we've got a long ways to go!
In 24 hours, the ISS makes 16 orbits of Earth, traveling through 16 sunrises and sunsets.
The International Space Station's main solar arrays drape across the Earth above the Pacific Ocean west of Hawaii.
alt: The International Space Station's main solar arrays over Earth.
title: Image by Nasa

fact: Peggy Whitson set the record for spending the most total time living and working in space at 665 days on Sept. 2, 2017
Mount Everest, the tallest mountain above sea level, is just 8.85km tall. At 900km, we've travelled the equivalent of 10 Mount Everests.
On-orbit software monitors approximately 350,000 sensors, ensuring station and crew health and safety.
This year (2020) marks the 20th anniversary of the International Space Station.
alt: A Nasa illustrated poster of Snoopy in space, celebrating the ISS 20th anniversary.
title: Image by Nasa

fact: More than 3 million lines of software code on the ground support more than 1.5 million lines of flight software code.
Did you know an astronaut can return to Earth up to two inches taller than when they left? The cartilage disks in the spine expand in the zero-g environment.
Through Expedition 58, the microgravity laboratory has hosted more than 2,700 research investigations from researchers in more than 103 countries.
This composite image, made from six frames, shows the International Space Station, with a crew of five onboard, in silhouette as it transits the Sun.
alt: Image composite showing the ISS travelling past the sun.
title: Image by Nasa

fact: The ISS is 357 feet end-to-end, one yard shy of the full length of an American football field including the end zones.
The ISS travels an equivalent distance to the Moon and back in about a day.
We're 1/100th of the way to the moon!
At 6430km, we've travelled the length of the Great Wall of China!
At 12,756km, we've travelled the diameter of Earth. The ISS must be on nearly the other end of the world compared to you!
